Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Odor-triggered Neuronal Dynamics and Experience-induced Olfactory Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will uncover neuronal network mechanisms that allow animals to recognize, and learn to recognize, different odors in their dynamic environment. The early stages of the hawkmoth Manduca sexta's olfactory system generate odor-specific responses which are spatiotemporally complex. Electrophysiological experiments, in conjunction with conditioning trials, will be carried out to determine which features of the complex response are in fact relevant to the moth's adaptive encoding of its olfactory environment, and how these features are resculpted when the moth learns to appreciate a new odor. Specifically, we will direct experiments measuring (a) high-order dynamical structures associated with odor-response in the hawkmoth's antennal lobe and other synaptic centers including the lateral protocerebrum and mushroom bodies, and (b) the plasticity-induced shift in these structures following a conditioning paradigm. These experiments will facilitate development of both computational and theoretical models of neuronal networks. Specifically, we will develop (c) a large-scale spiking network model of the hawkmoth olfactory system which will be benchmarked using the experiments mentioned above, and (d) a theoretical framework capable of analyzing the rich dynamics found in these networks.

An abundance of recent experiments indicate that insects as well as other animals such as mammals, primates and humans, exhibit brain states that are incredibly rich, some directly induced by stimuli and some born from learning processes, all possessing dynamic properties on a variety of scales. The intricacies of these dynamic regimes are still a mystery. We currently do not know what these brain states are capable of, nor how they are used to drive decision making or learning. The hawkmoth -- "Manduca sexta" -- has a brain which is considerably simpler than a human's, but nevertheless has an olfactory system not too dissimilar from our own. By investigating the link between neuronal network dynamics, behavior and learning within this animal, we will draw conclusions relevant to some of our basic cognitive functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this project are two folds. Intellectually, we aimed to examine an important hypothesis about how neurons in a network coordinate to produce signals that represent environmental stimuli for animals as well as for humans. More specifically, we recorded and analyzed responses of olfactory neurons in an insect model, and correlated the responses with well controlled odor stimuli and olfactory behaviors. All these data were used to benchmark our mathematical model. In addition to contributing new knowledge to the field of olfactory neuroscience, this project also aimed to bring broader impact to education of Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) in local communities and schools, provide training opportunities to students with variety of socioeconomic background. 

Intellectual contribution to specialty areas 

Neuronal synchrony, a phenomenon that multiple neurons elicit electric charges or spikes simultaneously, is believed to be an important code for stimuli. By characterizing a neural pathway in the male hawkmoth Manduca sexta that processes information about female sex pheromone (a 2-component odor mixture (A+B) in ratio of 2:1), we provided new evidence supporting the synchrony-code hypothesis. A key stage of the neural pathway is a network of neurons residing in the insect’s primary olfactory center called antennal lobe, which is equivalent to the olfactory bulb in the vertebrates. A specialized region in the antennal lobe of male moths processes the pheromone. This well-established chemical communication system offers a clear experimental advantage, that is, we can use a simple odor mixture (A+B) that is behaviorally effective. Using a series of odor mixtures deviating systematically from the natural 2:1 (A:B) ratio in wind-tunnel assays deteriorated these insects’ olfactory behaviors. We then carried out dual recordings from neurons that specifically process these mixtures, and discovered these neurons evoked largest amount of synchronized spikes upon stimulation with the 2:1 ratio. We went one step further, reasoning that if the synchrony-code was important, there must be downstream neurons that can read this code. We therefore recorded from these downstream neurons and challenged them with the same series of odor mixtures. Indeed, some of these neurons, not all of them, generated peak response when stimulated with the 2:1 ratio, corroborating with results from the antennal lobe and behavioral assays. Only with this approach could we establish the link between stimulus, neural response and behavior, all in one system. These results are published in J Comp Physiol A in 2013 (Martin et al., 2013; Lei et al., 2013). 

Inspired by experimental data, my collaborator Dr. Rangan in NYU developed a hybrid framework which combines certain techniques used by standard population-dynamics methods with the explicit use of stochastic methods for dealing with correlations amongst neurons and synchronous-events. Such a framework can be of considerable use not only in neuroscience but in the study of certain types of rare events in many physical systems. More importantly, the process of developing these models turned out to be a journey that mutually benefits both teams, i.e. experimentalists and theoreticians. Data from pharmacological experiments suggested a strong heterogeneity of inhibitory control in the special region of antennal lobe that processes sex pheromone; a model of multi-layer formulations not only explained the experimental observations but also predicted a particular phenomenon, namely run-away synchrony, in the other regions of the antennal lobe; these predictions were later confirmed with more experimental recordings. This process of discovery demonstrates a true collaboration between biologists and mathematicians, which is perhaps a key aspect of NSF collaborative programs. The results are published in Frontier Physiol in 2016 (Lei et al., 2016). 

We disseminated our findings through publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference presentations. From 2012-2016 we two teams published 6 original research articles and 1 review paper (see product list). Additionally, we also presented at international meetings such as the annual conference of Society for Neuroscience and others. 

Broader impact to society       

While gaining new insights on our specialty areas, we had in mind aligning our research with the educational goals of our institutes and NSF. We provided training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students (12 in Dr. Lei’s lab) with variety of ethnic and socioeconomic background. Building on the research experience obtained in this project, some undergraduate students are successfully admitted into top graduate schools in the nation. We assisted undergraduate students to attend the SfN conference. To most of the students, this was an eye-opening experience that triggered their enthusiasm in science. Taking opportunities of large community events such as the Tucson Festival of Books (https://tucsonfestivalofbooks.org/) and the Arizona Insect Festival (http://www.arizonainsectfestival.com/), we directly interacted with hundreds of local community members and groups each year, demonstrating electroantennagram (EAG), explaining how research on insect brains helps us to understand how our brain works. We also brought the demonstration to local elementary and middle schools, participating the schools’ STEM program.
